Do you know what type of roof you have? Different roof styles have different characteristics, maintenance needs, and even influence material choices. Let me walk you through the most common roof types.

Gable roofs are the most common type in America. They have two sloping sides that meet at a ridge, forming a triangular shape at the ends. They're simple, effective at shedding water and snow, provide good attic ventilation, and work with virtually any roofing material. The triangular ends can be vulnerable to wind damage, though.

Hip roofs have slopes on all four sides that meet at the top. They're more stable than gable roofs in high winds because there are no flat ends to catch the wind. They're common in hurricane-prone areas. The trade-off is they're more complex to build and roof, which increases costs.

Flat roofs aren't actually flat, they have a very slight slope for drainage. They're common on commercial buildings and modern homes. They offer usable outdoor space and are easier to install HVAC equipment on. They require different materials than sloped roofs and need good drainage to avoid water pooling.

Mansard roofs have four sides with two slopes on each side, the lower slope steeper than the upper. They create maximum attic space and are often used to add extra living area. The double slope can be challenging for roofing and maintenance.

Gambrel roofs look like barn roofs, with two slopes on each side, the lower one quite steep. They maximize upper-floor space and provide a distinctive look.

There are also shed roofs with a single slope, butterfly roofs that angle inward, sawtooth roofs common on industrial buildings, and various combination styles.

Why does roof type matter? It affects material choices, maintenance requirements, water drainage, snow load handling, wind resistance, and cost. Understanding your roof type helps you make better decisions about its care and replacement.

Your roof has a problem, but what exactly is wrong? Today I'm helping you identify common roofing issues, understand their causes, and know when to call for professional help.

Roof leaks are the most obvious problem and what usually drives people to call us. Leaks can come from damaged shingles, failed flashing, cracked vent boots, or dozens of other sources. The tricky part is the leak inside your house often isn't directly below where water is entering the roof. Water travels along rafters and decking before finding a way through. Tracking down the source requires experience.

Missing shingles are easy to spot from the ground. Storm winds are the usual culprit, but age and poor installation can cause them too. Each missing shingle is an exposed spot where water can get in. This needs prompt attention.

Damaged flashing around chimneys, vents, skylights, and roof edges is a major source of leaks. Flashing can corrode, separate from surfaces, or fail at joints. Often the damage isn't visible from the ground but shows up during inspection.

Ice dams happen in winter when heat escaping from your attic melts snow, which refreezes at the cold roof edge. The ice backs up, trapping water that can get under shingles and into your home. The fix usually involves addressing ventilation and insulation, not just the ice itself.

Moss and algae growth aren't just ugly. They can damage shingles over time. Moss holds moisture against the roof surface, and algae can eat away at shingle materials. Prevention and proper cleaning are the answers.

Sagging areas indicate structural issues that need immediate professional assessment. Poor ventilation leads to multiple problems including premature aging and moisture damage.

Don't ignore roofing problems hoping they'll stay the same. They always get worse. Early intervention saves money.
